user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_MutSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemDelete:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not find any compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code fragments. The function and related declarations use standard C constructs only: typedefs (int32 alias of int32_t and osal_id_t as uint32), a forward-declared struct typedef, macro constants (OS_SUCCESS), a normal function definition, local variables, function calls, and standard return statements. I looked specifically for common compiler extensions that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2, such as: __attribute__ or __declspec annotations, inline assembler (asm), GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, label-as-value, compiler-specific keywords or builtins (e.g. __builtin_*), nonstandard #pragmas shown in code, or other vendor-specific extensions. None of these appear in the supplied code. The ellipses (...) in the additional snippet indicate omitted unrelated content; they are not actual code and therefore not an extension. Consequently there are no suspicious fragments to escalate for further investigation under Rule 1.2.
